Sheikh Bomboli Tunis: "I don't think the temperature measurement is a good indicator of posdible ebola, taking into account the incubation period. ..false hope is not good."

Cecil Macauley: "The team at Bandama Check is formidable. I suggest you include 2 Megaphone announcers(1 Mende & 1 Krio) to pass on official status reports and guide passengers as we go through the process. A lot of people do not understand what goes on there and often go with misinformation."

" The minister said people are now more cooperative to take the tests and all the screening checkpoints are very “functional.”

She said 13 checkpoints have been established in the Kailahun, Kono and Kenema districts in the east of Sierra Leone.

“Each checkpoint is manned by four medical staff, and they are provided with cell phones, chlorine, disposable thermometers including gloves,” she said. "

Health worker: July 17 2014 

"Mr. Ahmed Samba, Health Ministry's National Laboratory Technician & Samples Transportation Expert. He has just tonight survived a terrible accident on the Bo Highway whilst transporting blood samples of suspected Ebola cases from Freetown. The ambulance was damaged reportedly beyond repairs; Windscreen, windows, steering wheel, everything, damaged. The driver and Lab technician Samba who were in the ambulance are both alive but with body pains. They are presently at Bo Government hospital. I have just spoken to Samba. He is such a brave patriot. Sadly, his money was looted at the scene whilst he laid unconscious. He is a brave guy whom, with the driver, has been involved in transporting these suspected samples for weeks now. God bless them. Meanwhile, the suspected Ebola samples were un-affected as Samba had professionally packed them using a shock proof method. They have already been forwarded to Kenema and received by the lab out there."

https://www.facebook.com/sylola/posts/746412578755508

July 15 2014 

"A victim who died of Ebola at the Connaught Hospital was yesterday buried at the Kingtom Cemetary.
The victim who is reported to be a male was put in a bodybag and buried hastily yesterday.
Confirming the case, the Chief Medical Officer Dr. Brima told Awoko in a telephone interview that the victim was one of those who had fled from Kenema and had been admitted at the Connaught hospital until his death on Sunday but the bad weather could allow his immediate burial until yesterday.
The other suspected case was quickly rushed to Kenema where he had come from and Dr. Kargbo said that these people are those running away from places like Kenema."

http://awoko.org/2014/07/15/sierra-leone-news-ebola-victim-dies-at-connaught-hospital/
https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=898687660147305&set=a.691478397534900.1073741831.100000182380160&type=1&permPage=1
 July 14 2014 

An Ebola patient who ran away from Kenema reportedly died at the Connaught Hospital yesterday.

This was confirmed by a health worker of the Ministry of Health and Sanitation during an interview with Sierra Express Media.

According to the health worker, the dead Ebola patient was first admitted at the Rokupr Hospital where she was diagnosed Ebola positive and was subsequently referred to the Connaught Hospital where she died.

Her corpse is said to be in the hospital mortuary.
- See more at: http://www.sierraexpressmedia.com/archives/69042#sthash.j1rphf8V.dpuf

http://sierraleonematters.co.uk/one-positive-ebola-case-at-connaught/

July 18 2014 

"The Ministry of Health and Sanitation also maintains pre-referral centres at Daru and Kuindu in Kailahun district with the support of Médecins Sans Frontières. These centres are for suspected cases until lab results have been received, then negative cases are discharged and positive cases are transferred to isolation wards. The Ministry of Health and Sanitation plans to open a centre in Lakka, Freetown, using equipment provided by Médecins Sans Frontières. PPE and chlorine continues to be in short supply."
